questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following lesions does not arise from the terminal duct lobular unit of the 
breast?
questions.explanation:
Periductal mastitis arises from the large lactiferous ducts. It is also known as squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts, recurrent subareolar abscess, or 
Zuska disease. The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is the basic functional and histopathological unit of the 
breast. Successive branching of large ducts eventually leads to the TDLU. Sclerosing adenosis, 
blue dome cyst, and carcinoma breast arise from the TDLU.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following lesions arise from the large ducts of the breast?
questions.explanation:
Duct ectasia and Paget's disease arise from the large ducts of the breast. Normal anatomy of the breast includes ducts, lobules, and stroma. Successive branching of the 
large ducts eventually leads to the terminal duct lobular unit. Atypical hyperplasia arises from the terminal ducts and lobules, whereas, fibroadenoma 
and phyllodes tumors arise from the intralobular stroma.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 28-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast. On examination, you 
notice her nipple is erythematous and tender with a purulent exudate. Which of the following 
is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastitis. The most common cause of acute 
mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breast 
abscess). It is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to 
cracks and fissures in the nipples. Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses. 1191 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Breast abscess caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is uncommon, only a few cases have 
been documented in immunocompromised patients. Options B and C: Streptococcal infections tend to spread throughout the breast in the form of 
cellulitis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following diseases is most strongly associated with a history of smoking?
questions.explanation:
Periductal mastitis is strongly associated with a history of smoking. More than 90% of the 
affected individuals are smokers. Periductal mastitis is also called recurrent subareolar abscess or squamous metaplasia of 
lactiferous ducts or Zuska disease. In this condition, a relative deficiency of vitamin A associated 
with smoking or toxic substances in tobacco smoke alters the differentiation of the ductal 
epithelium. Histologically, there is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts. Keratin shed from 
these cells is trapped and plugs (keratin plug) the ductal system, causing dilation and eventually 
rupture of the duct. This results in keratin spillage into the surrounding periductal tissue forming 
a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response. It presents with a painful erythematous subareolar mass that clinically mimics bacterial abscess. 
It has a high recurrence rate.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had 
sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a 
radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent 
cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis. About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or 
previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or 1192 
Sold by @itachibot mammographic densities or calcifications. Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and 
chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification. The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue. Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions - • Apocrine cysts • Hyalinized fibroadenomas • Sclerosing adenosis • Duct ectasia • Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification 
(microcalcifications).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a proliferative breast lesion?
questions.explanation:
Papillomas are classified under proliferative breast diseases without atypia. Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and usually have no genetic changes. 
Thus they are predictors of risk but are not true precursors of carcinoma. Benign epithelial lesions are classified into three groups, according to the subsequent risk of 
developing breast cancer. These are: • Non-proliferative breast changes • Proliferative breast disease without atypia • Atypical hyperplasia Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with 
associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of 1193 
Sold by @itachibot metastases.

questions.question: Question 7: All of the following lesions are proliferative breast lesions without atypia except:
questions.explanation:
Duct ectasia is a non-proliferative breast change. Radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, and florid hyperplasia belong to proliferative breast lesions 
without atypia. Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and are not commonly found to have 
genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but unlikely to be true precursors of carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 8: What is the most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma? 1180 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma is nipple 
discharge. More than 80% of large duct papillomas produce a nipple discharge. Papillomas grow within a dilated duct and are composed of multiple branching fibrovascular 
cores. It can be serous or bloody. • Serous discharge - due to intermittent blockage and release of normal breast secretions or 
irritation of the duct by the papilloma • Bloody discharge - due to torsion of the stalk, causing infarction

questions.question:
Question 9: A young man presents to your clinic with the following finding. Which of the following is not 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The image given depicts gynecomastia. Seminoma is not a cause of this condition. Gynecomastia occurs due to increased estrogenic action. The most common causes of 
gynecomastia include: • Cirrhosis of the liver • Alcohol • Mari˜uana, heroin • Antiretroviral therapy • Anabolic steroids • Klinefelter syndrome (››Y karyotype) • Functioning testicular neoplasms such as Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors Microscopically, there is an increase in the dense collagenous connective tissue. It is associated 
with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule 
formation is almost never observed. 1194 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A biopsy was performed on a female patient who presented with a lump in her right breast. 
Presence of which of the following findings is not associated with an increased risk of cancer?
questions.explanation:
Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change. Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are 
classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of 
carcinoma. Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly 
higher.

questions.question:
Question 11: While undergoing a routine mammogram, a 45-year-old woman was found to have clusters of 
microcalcification in her right breast. A needle biopsy was done and revealed the following. 
Which of the following markers can be used to rule out invasive disease?
questions.explanation:
The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). 
Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma. 1195 
Sold by @itachibot DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the 
intact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography. Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence the 
myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS 
whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may be 
diminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules. Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma, 
they are considered to be invasive carcinoma. Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with 
associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of 
metastases.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 55-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness and itching in her right nipple. On 
examination, the following finding is noted. What would be the next best step in her 
management? 1182 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario showing a red eczematous rash over the areola of the breast is suggestive 
of Paget's disease of the nipple. The next best step in management is biopsy of the nipple. Paget's disease can be mistaken for eczema, and hence, biopsy of the nipple should be the initial 
management of choice. Paget cells are readily detected by nipple biopsy.

questions.question:
Question 13: Histopathological examination of a middle-aged woman who presented with redness and 
itching over the nipple of her left breast is given below. Which of the following statements is 
incorrect about her condition?

options.c: Prognosis depends on the underlying carcinoma
options.d: The cells show overexpression of HER2

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant pale 
cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells are 
ER-negative. Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). The characteristic 
Paget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach 1196 
Sold by @itachibot the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin. The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane. It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen in 
about half the patients with this disease. The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. 
The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma. Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions: • Eczema (clinical appearance) - can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsy • Superficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive and 
diastase resistant unlike melanoma cells Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolism 
due to osteoclastic overactivity. 1197 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is not a risk factor for breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Early full-term pregnancy (younger than 20 years) is protective against breast cancer. It halves the 
risk of developing breast cancer compared to that of nulliparous women. Women with very dense breasts on mammography have a four- to six-fold higher risk of both 
ER-positive and ER-negative breast cancer compared to women with low density. Obese women under the age of 40 years have a decreased risk as a result of anovulatory cycles and 
lower progesterone levels. In contrast, postmenopausal obese women are at an increased risk, 
which is attributed to the synthesis of estrogens in fat depots. Early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity are risk factors of breast cancer due to 
hyperestrogenemia. Exercise and breastfeeding are protective against breast cancer.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast?
questions.explanation:
The upper outer quadrant is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast. Approximately 50% of carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant, 10% in each of the 
remaining quadrants, and about 20% in the central or subareolar region. A palpable mass is the most common clinical sign of invasive breast carcinoma. Triple assessment is recommended for the diagnosis of any palpable breast lump. It includes: • Clinical examination • Radiological assessment (mammography/USG) • Pathological assessment (FNAC/biopsy) Techniques of palpation for breast examination are: • Vertical strip/lines pattern • Circular pattern • Wedges or radial spokes pattern 1198 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: On which of the following chromosomes is the BRCA2 gene located?
questions.explanation:
BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3). Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single gene familial breast 
cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers. ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) is the most common subtype of breast cancer 
in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently 
with male breast cancer. Single gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into: • High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, 
STK11, CDH I, PALPB2 • Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2

questions.question:
Question 17: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with 
breast cancer. It revealed lack of expression of ER, PR, and HER2. Which of the following 
genes is most commonly mutated in this condition? 1184 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of triple-negative breast cancer (ER-negative, PR-negative, and 
HER2-negative). TP53 is the most commonly mutated gene in triple-negative breast cancer 
(TNBC). Common gene mutations in the 3 ma˜or molecular types of invasive breast carcinoma are: Molecular Subtype 
Common gene mutations Luminal (ER+/HER2 
-) Luminal A: PIK3CA (more co 
mmon), TP53Luminal B: PIK 
3CA (more common), TP53 1199 
Sold by @itachibot Molecular Subtype 
Common gene mutations HER2 Positive (HER 
2+) TP53 (more common), PIK3C 
A TNBC (ER-/ HER2-) 
TP53 (more common), PIK3C 
A

questions.question:
Question 18: A 44-year-old woman has been diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry 
staining of a tissue biopsy specimen of this patient is given below. Which of the following 
statements is true regarding her condition?

options.b: It is not associated with tP53 mutations

questions.explanation:
The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), and 
negative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal A 
molecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel. Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR–positive breast cancer 
cells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and 
hence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes. Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents like 
tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is a 
recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2. The following image shows ER/ PR/ Her-2 positivity: Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations are 
associated with triple-negative tumors as well.

questions.question:
Question 19: Immunohistochemistry test of a breast cancer patient was reported negative for ER and 
HER2. This molecular subtype includes all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
1200 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinomas with immunohistochemistry ER and HER2/ negative are all of the above except 
mucinous carcinomas. Mucinous carcinomas are usually ER-positive and HER2/neu negative 
(luminal A type) ER-negative, HER2-negative (triple-negative) molecular subtype commonly includes the 
following histological subtypes: • Medullary • Adenoid cystic • Secretory • Metaplastic • Spindle cell • Squamous • Matrix-producing

questions.question:
Question 20: Patients with all of the following conditions have ER-positive and HER2-negative tumors 
except:
questions.explanation:
ER-positive, HER2-negative status on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of the luminal type of 
breast carcinoma, which does not include secretory carcinoma. The ER-positive, HER2-negative molecular subtype (luminal type) commonly includes the 
following histological subtypes: • Well and poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma • Tubular carcinoma • Mucinous carcinoma • Papillary carcinoma Secretory carcinomas are usually ER-negative and Her2/neu negative (basal type).

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following breast cancers most commonly presents as an occult primary 
carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Lobular carcinoma is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary 
carcinoma. Lobular carcinoma of the breast is seen bilaterally and with multicentricity. Loss of E-cadherin is 
the hallmark of lobular carcinoma. They also have characteristic patterns of metastatic spread, 
often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis), 
gastrointestinal tract, ovaries, and uterus. The histological hallmark of lobular carcinoma is the presence of discohesive infiltrating tumor 
cells, often arranged in a single Indian file pattern or in loose clusters or sheets. 1201 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is not a feature of lobular breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
There is no or very slight desmoplastic response seen in lobular carcinomas. Desmoplasia refers to collagenous stromal proliferation induced by tumor cells which is essential 
for tumor growth and spread. It results in hard and stony tumors. However, this is not seen in 
lobular carcinoma. This is likely due to the loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that 
encodes e-cadherin (normally maintains intercellular adhesiveness). This also results 
in disaggregation of cells. Lobular carcinomas are often bilateral and multicentric. It shows characteristic metastatic spread, 
often involving: • Peritoneum and retro peritoneum • Leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis) • Gastrointestinal tract • Ovaries • Uterus Histopathological image of invasive lobular carcinoma of breast showing discohesive cells with 
few signet ring cells. 1202 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Individuals with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 (loss of E-cadherin) also have a 
greatly increased risk of gastric signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 53-year-old woman with breast cancer is found to have TNM staging of T4dN0M0. Which 
of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

options.a: There is loss of e-cadherin expression
options.b: It has a relatively favorable prognosis
options.c: There is obstruction of dermal lymphatics by neoplastic cells
options.d: History of trauma to the breast is usually present

questions.explanation:
T4d in the TNM staging of carcinoma breast points toward a diagnosis of inflammatory breast 
carcinoma. It shows extensive invasion and proliferation of tumor cells within the dermal 
lymphatics leading to obstruction. Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The hallmark of this 
condition is the overexpression of e-cadherin. This results in increased tumor cohesion and the 
formation of tumoral clumps which can result in emboli. It has a particularly poor prognosis. 1203 
Sold by @itachibot These tumors are usually of high grade but do not belong to any particular molecular 
subtype. More than half (60%) are ER-negative and 40% to 50% overexpress HER2. There is no 
association with trauma. Due to lymphatic obstruction, it results in brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and 
edema called peau d’orange appearance. This may mimic non-neoplastic inflammatory lesions 
like mastitis. A breast lump may or may not be present. The following image shows a peau d’orange appearance of the right breast.

questions.question:
Question 24: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breast 
carcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be sub˜ected to 
fluorescence in-situ hybridization?
questions.explanation:
The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential 
staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. 
Hence, she should be sub˜ected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm 
HER2-positive gene amplification status. 1204 
Sold by @itachibot 1205 
Sold by @itachibot The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors: • Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed). • Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with 
trastuzumab or lapatinib.

questions.question:
Question 25: A middle-aged woman is diagnosed with low-grade mucinous carcinoma of the breast. IHC 
showed HER2 overexpression and a low Ki67 index. Which of the following would be 
considered as a poor prognostic factor?
questions.explanation:
HER2 overexpression in a patient with carcinoma breast is associated with poor survival. The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target this 
receptor. Prognostic and predictive factors in breast carcinoma: Good prognosis 
Bad prognosis Extent and spread

carcinomaLobular carcinoma

cystic carcinoma Metaplastic carcinomaMicro 
papillary carcinoma Histologic grade 
Low grade

ype Low proliferation rate

& mitotic counts)

questions.question:
Question 26: A 30-year-old woman on cyclosporin-A following renal transplantation developed multiple 
bilateral breast lumps that regressed after cessation of treatment. ■Her biopsy finding is 
shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing duct proliferation are suggestive of fibroadenomas. The 
use of cyclosporin-A after transplantation is associated with fibroadenomas that regress after 
cessation of the treatment. 1206 
Sold by @itachibot Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. Nearly 2/3 cases are 
associated with mutations in the MED12 gene. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women <30 years of age. They 
are solid, well-defined, highly mobile masses (also known as breast mice). Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types: • Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition • With complex features - • Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary 
apocrine change • Classified as proliferative changes without atypia

questions.question:
Question 27: A 58-year-old woman presented with a large, rapidly growing painless breast lump. On 
examination, a smooth, multinodular breast lump was noticed. Microscopic examination of 
the core biopsy sample is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement 
regarding this condition? 1188 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Stromal cellularity is increased next to the epithelium
options.c: Absence of epithelial elements suggests malignancy
options.d: Both epithelial and stromal components can metastasize

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromal 
component is involved in metastasis. 1207 
Sold by @itachibot Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a 
smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It most 
commonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with: • Gain in chromosome 1q • HO›B13 overexpression Phyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial or 
periepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma. The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors are 
low grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize. The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are: • Markedly increased stromal cellularity • Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements 1208 
Sold by @itachibot • Nuclear atypia • Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf) • Highly recurrent Regardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph node 
dissection is contraindicated.

questions.question: Question 28: What is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast?
questions.explanation:
Angiosarcoma is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast. It arises in the interlobular stroma and accounts for < 0.05% of breast malignancies. It is a 
high-grade tumor with a poor prognosis. It can either be sporadic or occur in association with 
radiation therapy. The mean age of affected individuals is 35 years.

questions.question:
Question 29: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of which of the following 
conditions?
questions.explanation:
BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of renal cell carcinoma. BRCA-2 mutation predisposes to the development of prostate and pancreatic cancer. It is also 
associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.

questions.question:
Question 30: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. 
Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast. Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular 
mucin deposition. On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged 
in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the 
periphery to form a signet ring appearance. 1209 
Sold by @itachibot Coiioid Carcinoma of Breast Coiioid Carcinoma of Breast Option B: Microscopic image of papillary carcinoma of the breast showing true papillae with a 
leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue lined by the tumor cells is shown below. 1210 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Microscopic image of medullary carcinoma of the breast consisting of sheets of highly 
pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures (anaplastic cells), lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is shown 
below. 1211 
Sold by @itachibot Histology of lweclullary ca re irio ma breast Option D: Microscopic image of lobular carcinoma of the breast shows infiltrating small 
monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern is shown 
below. LC›buIar carcinoma of breast 1212 
Sold by @itachibot Developmental disorders,infections and tumors of bone
